topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Tristan opens with the idea that people adopt an unnatural “public speaking voice.” Lenny introduces Tristan’s credentials and frames the episode as tactical, interactive practice to improve public speaking and anxiety.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Two sponsor reads: Eppo (experimentation/A-B testing platform) and Command AI (in-product AI support and nudges).

topics.title: Speaking as a meta-skill and “debugging” yourself
topics.summary: Tristan argues the biggest misconception is underestimating how transformative speaking is because it’s a meta-skill. He explains the “hardware vs. buggy software” metaphor: humans are built to speak, but habits and avoidance create bugs that can be debugged and upgraded.

topics.title: Enjoyment as a barometer for speaking well
topics.summary: They discuss Tristan’s principle: if you don’t enjoy speaking, you’re likely doing it wrong. Enjoyment signals you’re speaking more naturally (like in personal conversations) and practicing in a sustainable way.

topics.title: Flow state and fixing root causes, not symptoms
topics.summary: Tristan explains speaking is a subconscious, flow-oriented process; the goal is staying in flow rather than adding conscious tactics. He advocates addressing root causes (comfort with pausing, trust, certainty) instead of symptoms like filler words or monotone delivery.

topics.title: Three tactical tweaks: think up, end strong, stay in character
topics.summary: Tristan shares three practical tactics: look up while thinking to appear thoughtful/confident, “end strong” using summary prompts to avoid tapering off, and “stay in character” by not leaking insecurities or hedging mid-speech.

topics.title: Why people “leak” and how to stop
topics.summary: Lenny relates to apologizing/flagging when things feel off; Tristan explains it’s driven by the false belief the audience can tell. They use analogies (standup, train, pilot announcements) to show how calling attention to mistakes worsens audience perception.

topics.title: Why Ultraspeaking uses games for practice
topics.summary: They transition into live exercises and discuss why games work: you can’t improve without speaking, and games create short deliberate reps with feedback. Tristan describes how the curriculum evolved from coaching experiments into structured speaking games and tools.

topics.title: Live game: Conductor explained and demoed
topics.summary: Tristan explains Conductor: speaking to a random prompt while adjusting intensity based on changing numbers and pausing on “breathe.” He demonstrates on the prompt “When I grow up,” showing controlled shifts in energy and pacing.

topics.title: Lenny plays Conductor; coaching on mindset
topics.summary: Lenny attempts Conductor (“The Greatest Puzzle”), struggles to fully commit to the game, and Tristan coaches him to prioritize play over performance. Lenny tries again (“Integrating new cultures”) and they note reduced leaking/hedging.

topics.title: Turbulence training and lessons from Conductor
topics.summary: Tristan frames games as flight simulators designed to create “turbulence,” teaching graceful recovery and confidence under pressure. Lenny shares takeaways: different energy levels unlock different thoughts (“folders”), and low-stakes reps build real confidence; Tristan adds the model: energy → emotion → words.
